conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your question. In practical terms, the point at which we would consider higher-priority candidates “fully resolved” is when the admissions process reaches a stage where (a) those higher-priority students have already formed matches elsewhere and are no longer participating, or (b) the process is near its end and it becomes clear that no higher-priority candidate will be applying to School_C for the remaining seat.

Because this is a round-based matching process and students’ choices can change from round to round, there is not a single earlier milestone we can promise (such as a specific document or interview) that would trigger an offer. We continue holding the seat while there remains a realistic possibility that a higher-priority candidate may still approach School_C.

If we reach a point where the seat would otherwise remain unfilled after higher-priority candidates are effectively no longer in play, we would then be able to reconsider and potentially extend an offer to you.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
